items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River and lake levels have now peaked on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water. and with only a few showers expected throughout the day we expect the levels to fall. Areas still affected are locations around Derwent Water, with low lying land expected to be most affected. This message will be updated tomorrow, the 01/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ditton catchment including areas around Huyton-with-Roby and Widnes

floodArea.county: Halton, Knowsley, Liverpool, St. Helens, Warrington

items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold on 31/12/21.  Further rainfall is due this week. We will continue to monitor the situation and reissue the alert if necessary.  Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation.

River levels remain high at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury including the B3493 near Llansantffraid Bridge. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. 
At 4pm the level at the Maesbrook guage was 1.38m and steady. The level at the Cae Howel guage was 3.98m and rising slowly. Llanymynech peaked at 4.1m overnight.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 9am on Saturday 01/01/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Crew Green river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. Predicted Peaks:- Crew Green peaking now at 5.62m, Montford 4.8 to 5.1m on Saturday morning 01/01/22, Welshbridge 2.5 to 2.8m on Saturday afternoon, Buildwas 3.6 to 4.0m overnight on Saturday, Bridgnorth 2.8 to 3.2m Sunday morning 02/01/22.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high over the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 9am on Saturday 01/01/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the past few days. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue for the next couple of days. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days and we expect river levels to remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 9am on Saturday 01/01/22 or if the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Milford river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook.   We do not forecast the situation to deteriorate any further.
We expect river levels to remain high.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message: River levels remain high at the Sherbourne Lake river gauge but are falling. There is no further risk of additional flooding at this time. We continue to monitor the situation.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  No further rainfall is forecast this evening.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses, plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels have risen and remain high at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the past few days. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue for the next couple of days. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. As further rainfall is expected river levels will remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated by 9am on Saturday 01/01/22 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message: River levels are continuing to rise slowly on the River Dee. Flooding remains possible at low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington throughout today (31/12/2021) and into tomorrow morning (1/1/2022). The River Dee is expected to peak at lunchtime tomorrow at 8.2m and then begin to gradually drop. Please be aware that Townfield Lane could be cut off. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning (1/1/2022), or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are falling slowly on the lower River Ray. Flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue overnight (31/12/21), particularly in the Islip area. 
The forecast is for a dry night with the chance of light passing showers tomorrow (01/01/22). River levels in the Islip area are dropping slowly, but will remain high and sensitive to further rainfall over the coming days. River levels upstream of Lower Arncott are now below the flood risk threshold.
We are monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, many of which will be flooded. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 01/01/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Hillfarrance Brook, Halsewater Stream, River Tone
Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message: River levels remain high at the Beggearn Huish river gauge as a result of overnight rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible through today, 31/12/21.  Flooding may affect the Horner Water, Rivers Aller and Washford, and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and tributaries. Flooding of properties is not forecast. No significant rainfall is forecast for today. We expect river levels to remain high until this evening, 31/12/21. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded, and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 11:00 tomorrow, 1/1/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brue, River Sheppey, North Drain, South Drain

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are falling slowly on the River Thame. Flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue overnight (31/12/21) especially in areas between Stadhampton and Dorchester. 
The forecast is for a dry night with the chance of light passing showers tomorrow (01/01/22). River levels between Stadhampton and Dorchester are falling slowly but will remain high and sensitive to further rainfall over the coming days. Levels upstream of Thame are below the flood risk threshold.
We are monitoring the situation.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, many of which will be flooded. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 01/01/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. Further rainfall is forecast tomorrow, 01/01/22, so we will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are slowly falling on the Chertsey Bourne following recent rainfall. The forecast is dry overnight, with further showers possible tomorrow, 01/01/22.  We are closely monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and remain safe and aware of your local surroundings.  This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 01/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high but are falling slowly on the Lower Cherwell. Flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue overnight (31/12/21) especially in Thrupp and Kidlington areas. 
The forecast is for a dry night with the chance of light passing showers tomorrow (01/01/22). River levels around Thrupp and Kidlington are dropping slowly but will remain high and sensitive to further rainfall over the coming days. Levels on the River Cherwell in the Oxford and Upper Heyford areas are below the flood risk threshold.
We are monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, many of which will be flooded. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 01/01/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels in the Eastern Yar are falling and the situation is improving. Showers are possible on Saturday 1/1/22 and Sunday 2/1/22. If this rain falls on the Eastern Yar then river levels will rise again. Residents are recommended to keep flood protection products ready. We will continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels are high at the Sutton Gault river gauge and the Welney Causeway Guage as a result of rainfall earlier this week. We expect flooding to affect The Causeway at Sutton Gault and the A1101 Wash Road at Welney.
This information is correct as of 15:45 on Friday 31st December. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 12 centimetres of water currently on the road, and lower sections of the Welney Causeway are beginning to flood. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
There are currently no issues on the Earith Causeway. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the weekend.  Therefore we expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with Highways Teams, who will decide whether to close the road.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 01/01/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high at the Sutton Gault river gauge as a result of rainfall earlier this week.  
This information is correct as of 15:45 on Friday 31st December. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 12 centimetres of water currently on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
This alert applies to SUTTON GAULT CAUSEWAY ONLY.
Further light rainfall is forecast over the weekend, therefore we expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with Highways Teams, who will decide whether to close the road.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 01/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels remain high but stable at the Bradford on Avon river gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from today, 31/12/2021 and into tomorrow 01/01/2022.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high but relatively stable for at least the next 48 hours.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on Saturday, 01/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.message: The flood alert for the Lower River Ure remains in force due to rising river levels. This is in response to prolonged rainfall overnight. Levels are now peaking in the upper reaches of the catchment, but levels in the lower reaches of the catchment are still rising and will continue to do so through today, Friday 31st December. Some further showers are expected at times today, with weather conditions remaining unsettled for the coming days. For a more detailed weather forecast for your area, please see the Met Office www.metoffice.gov.uk. Please stay aware of your surroundings and do not put yourself at risk. We are monitoring the situation closely. This message will be updated by 9pm on Friday 31st December 2021, or as the situation develops.

This message will be updated tomorrow, the 01/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ehen, Rive Calder, River Irt, River Esk

items.message:
River levels have dropped below Flood Alert thresholds and are not expected to rise again with a relatively dry weather forecast as the rainfall eases.
No property flooding is expected.
River levels are now returning to normal. We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger

River levels have risen overnight on the Lower River Eden due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding of low lying land and roads is forecast to affect locations near the Lower River Eden, particularly around River Eden and its tributaries from its confluence with the River Irthing through Crosby-on-Eden and Carlisle to the Solway Firth at Rockcliffe during today 31/12/2021. The forecast for today is to be drier and therefore river levels will start to recede.
Further showery rainfall is forecast throughout tomorrow (Saturday) but we do not expect any further flooding impacts.
We are clearing debris from weed screens in the area and we continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated tomorrow, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Eden at Carlisle, Rickerby Park, Swifts and Stoneyholme Golf Courses

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message:
River levels are rising on the River Ouse due to overnight rainfall in the Dales. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ouse, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith, and South Esplanade. Further rain showers are forecast during tomorrow, with levels expected to peak late morning tomorrow, Saturday 1st January 2022.

We will continue to monitor levels closely. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences along the River Ouse in York. The Foss Barrier will be in operation from later today. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 31/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message:
River levels are rising on the River Ouse, due to overnight rainfall in the Dales. Areas most at risk include The tidal foreshore and agricultural land adjacent to the river in the Cawood, Kelfield, Wistow and Selby areas. Further rain showers are forecast during tomorrow, with levels expected to peak late morning tomorrow, Saturday 1st January 2022.

We will continue to monitor levels closely. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences along the River Ouse in York. The Foss Barrier will be in operation from later today.  Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 

This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 31/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ure at Roecliffe Caravan Park
items.message:
River levels are rising on the River Ure due to rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ure, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Roecliffe Caravan Park. Flooding is affecting Roecliffe Caravan Park from 03:30 PM on 31/12/2021.

The forecast is dry for throughout the afternoon and this evening, with some showers expected tomorrow. River levels will start to fall overnight. For the latest flood and river information please visit gov.uk/flood. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 31/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising on the River Pont at Stamfordham Heugh Mill due to heavy rainfall overnight.
Flooding is possible on riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads from 14:30, today, 31/12/2021 until tomorrow morning, 01/01/2022.
We are closely monitoring the situation and no property flooding is expected.
No further heavy rainfall is forecast and river levels will start to fall this evening.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00, tomorrow, 01/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 08:00 AM on 01/01/2022. the Alert will be in force for 2 hours either side of this time.
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon.
Our incident response staff have closed relevant flood gates and have been checking defences.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Spring tides are building over the weekend, we are currently forecasting the need for flood alerts to be in force for tides on both Sunday and Monday. We will re-issue this alert should this forecast indicate the need.
We will remove this message by 12:00 noon on 01/01/2022.

River levels have risen and are high at the Welney Causeway river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall earlier this week. We expect flooding to affect The A1101 Wash Road at Welney. 
This information is correct as of 16:00 on Friday 31st December. Lower sections of the causeway at Welney are beginning to flood. Throughout the evening and overnight we expect levels to rise further. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
There are currently no issues on the Earith Causeway. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the weekend, therefore whilst levels may fluctuate, we expect them to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the road.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning 01/01/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising on the River Ouse due to recent rainfall in the Dales. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ouse, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Naburn Lock Buildings and Lock Cottages. Flooding is expected at Naburn Lock Buildings and Lock Cottages from 03:00 AM on 01/01/2022. No further significant rainfall is forecast. River levels are rising at the York Viking Recorder gauge and are expected to peak in York mid-morning on 01/01/2022.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. We will continue to work with emergency services and local authorities and to keep closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 11:00 PM on 31/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - riverside properties
items.message:
River levels are rising on the River Ouse due to recent rainfall in the Dales. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ouse, with low lying land expected to be most affected around riverside properties, roads and paths within York city centre, particularly around King's Staith and riverside areas through York from Scarborough Bridge to the Millennium Bridge.

Riverside floodgates have been closed, and the Foss Barrier will be operating later this evening. No further significant rainfall is forecast. River levels at the York Viking Recorder gauge are expected to peak in York mid-morning on 01/01/2022 at approximately 3.10m.

For the latest flood information and river levels visit gov.uk/flood. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any roads near watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 11:00 PM on 31/12/2021, or as the situation changes.
